/COMMIT_MSG.message:
I don't see that this is actually in this change. That's ok - but if you respin this for any other reason it would be good to remove this from the commit message.

Also - FWIW - self.skipTest() is a better choice than raise SkipTest ... but again, this doesn't really happen in this patch.

Agree this can be removed. As background though, a couple things here.

This was in the class setup, so self.skipTest() is not an option at that point since there is no self. Not as common of a situation.

The other issue encountered with using the inherited skipTest() versus raising the exception directly was due to transitioning with the standard unittest module versus the unittest2 package. We currently inherit a lot from unittest2 base classes, so it ends up calling skipTest raises a unittest2.SkipException, whereas the test running would only be looking for a unittest.SkipException.

I think the best fix for that is to have unittest2's SkipException inherit from unittest.SkipException, but considering it's been years since unittest2 has done a release, the best path forward, IMO, is to start migrating away from any direct unittest2 usage. It's not really needed now in a py3-only world.

nova/policies/admin_actions.py.message:
I am confused... we are deprecating a policy that never existed?

This is sure to cause some issues when folks have an existing override, they will get no warnings :/

yeah, we can go with step wise
- make scope enable by default (change default value of [oslo_policy].enforce_scope to True).
- Deprecate [oslo_policy].enforce_scope
- Remvoe [oslo_policy].enforce_scope means operator cannot disable scope in any way.

I probably see why John thinks we needn't deprecated anything here. Since the rule still existing here. We just want to notice the user, there is new feature which enable system scope policy, then notice user update their existing configure. So that isn't about deprecate thing, maybe we can do that by release note? Sounds like we will keep the legacy way and system scope way. If someday we want to deprecate the legacy way, we can deprecate the `[oslo_policy] enforce_scope` option.

ah i need to make it with full string.

rule name is the same here for all rules but this rule needs deprecation because default value is changed. explaining the same in next comment.

You know, I am not sure we need to deprecate anything here... doesn't this "just work" for any user that it used to work for, and you get to opt into the scope check via config if you want to, so we don't need any deprecation here?

I don't think we don't need to update the rule for this case...

Users opt into the new behaviour by switching the enforce_scope = True, which eventually we will make the default for Nova.

If we add this rule, it doesn't really change anything, excpet warning users that override a new rule we just invented, that by definition no one can be overriding it yet. i.e. no one sees any extra info.

An alternative would be if the rule could check if scopes are enforced or not, and do the right thing. In that case we don't need to deprecate and "or" in the old rule.

on scope_type, you are right we do not need any deprecation warning which can be enabled/disabled via config.

But by changing the check_str to SYSTEM_ADMIN actually we are changing the check_str from the previous RULE_ADMIN_API value.
For deployment where system_scope is disabled, Our system rule contains the special string 'system_scope:all' to avoid the project admin to access this API. 

SYSTEM_ADMIN is 'role:admin and system_scope:all'.

for backward compatibility, we need to deprecate the rule with old default RULE_ADMIN_API (here deprecation is for the default value, not the name.) so that old legacy admin token keeps working.
I might not be understanding your point completely but let me rebase this without deprecation with the new tests in base patch. that can give a better idea of what all things keep working.

Patchset 4 was closer to what this should be. It does not matter that the rules in 701624 have deprecation labels. Without the deprecation label here, this rule will suddenly change its meaning without any ability to fall back to its old behavior.

Actually there is no change in 'os_compute_api:os-admin-actions:reset_state' policy here. RULE_ADMIN_API rule with scope_type as 'system' is the same as SYSTEM_ADMIN. so we are not changing anything here so does not fall under deprecating this policy. This is what John point was in PS4.

If there is change in the specific rule then yes we do deprecate like done in - https://review.opendev.org/#/c/648480/23/nova/policies/services.py

tldr I think you're right but I wrote out my thought process for clarity:

RULE_ADMIN_API with scope_type 'system' is only the same as SYSTEM_ADMIN when enforce_scope=true. The policy with name "os_compute_api:os-admin-actions:reset_state" is changing its check string from "is_admin:True" to an effective check string of "(role:admin and system_scope:all) or (is_admin:True)". Without the deprecation parameter, the operator isn't notified of this change and has no opportunity to override this individual rule to opt into the more secure "role:admin and system_scope:all" check string.

If the idea is for the operator to turn on enforce_scope and cut over all the policies at once, then this is probably fine. After thinking about it for a while I think this is probably the right approach.

but new rule SYSTEM_ADMIN has the deprecated rule of old rule RULE_ADMIN_API so oslo policy will do logical OR with both of them and when os_compute_api:os-admin-actions:%s check_str is checked it will do RuleCheck and take care of both rule (new and deprecated). 

That is why the existing test using old context is working fine[1] otherwise it will fail.

So instead of deprecating each policy rule, we decided to deprecate base Rule which is being used in every policy rule. 

[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/c16315165ce307c605cf4b608b2df3aa06f46982/nova/tests/unit/policies/test_admin_actions.py

I see now that you're correct that it works technically. Unfortunately it doesn't give the right deprecation warning in the logs. Instead of oslo.policy warning about the "os_compute_api:os-admin-actions:reset_state" policy, there are just repetitions of warnings about the "os_compute_api:os-services":"rule:admin_api" policy. This means the operator doesn't have the ability to selectively opt into the new behavior on a rule by rule basis because they can't see what rules are really changing.

os_net_config/utils.py.message:
Dpdk mapping file is required only when the interface is not visible to the kernel. Inorder to re-create the same nic numbering, we need dpdk mapping file. But mellanox case, We dont need to add it to DPDK mapping file, as the interfaces will still visible to the user.

What we need to fix is that when we try to access the information, instead of mapping file, get it from the actual interface itself, if the interface is visible.
This special handling is needed only for mellanox cx3 interfaces, in which both ports of a nic has same pci address. This check should not be altered.

alternate way is to add elif condition to check if the ifname is still active (in case of intel nics it will not be visible to kernel). if the ifname is visibile, get the pci address directly instead of using get_stored_pci_address function.
Its good to have an else part with a log message.

Okay, but the migration cases are by far the least likely reason to get an instance lifecycle event. Done
Lazy load feels like a performance optimization that can be done later, separately.

> Shouldn't we just let that lazy-load in that case so we don't penalize all lifecycle event processing?

We could, and that's what it was doing before I added this.

> Alternatively, we could move this to after we examine the lifecycle event and only load it if we're likely to need it (i.e. event_transition in migrate_finish_statuses)?

Yup, could also do that which makes the logic a tiny bit more complicated but not really an issue to change it that way. I just wasn't sure if it was worth splitting those hairs since by default we always join on info_cache anyway in the DB API, this was just one of the rare places where we actually passed expected_attrs=[] to not do the default join.

I'm not sure if that means we get multiple events (one suspended with no details, then the specific ones). I could probably figure that out from the live migration job logs in the next patch in the series though. I also think _sync_instance_power_state is supposed to be smart enough to not try and change anything if there are no changes between what's in the db for the instance and the what the hypervisor says about the guest power state.

plugins/modules/os_coe_cluster.py.message: Please don't remove existing parameter without deprecation cycle. We can add new parameter and manage backward compatibility.

I have not removed anything. I am merely reflecting what is already happening. If you run this module yourself, you will see that the output is actually `id` and not `uuid` as this documentation claims. `uuid` is only returned when a cluster gets created, in an instance where it doenst already exist.

Add:

  cluster['id'] = cluster_id
  cluster['uuid'] = cluster_id

That way both directions of failures will be fixed.

tasks/upgrade/overcloud_upgrade_run.yml.message: nit: This should be singular now.

This causes the result to always be 'success' which is not what you want. Have the next task fail when the rc != 0. Something like this is quite efficient because it will only loop through the failures:

    - name: "Show failure message for any roles that failed"
      fail:
        msg: "The overcloud upgrade for {{ item.item }} failed"
      loop: "{{ overcloud_upgrade_nodes.results | selectattr('rc', 'ne', 1) | list }}"

I don't understand why do we need to loop over overcloud_upgrade_nodes.results if the command above is being run now only once, now that the loop: "{{ oc_roles|default(['all']) }}" has been removed... What's overcloud_upgrade_nodes.results containing?

Oh duh, silly me - I was looking at the 'before', not the 'after'.

Anyway, the point is that 'when: overcloud_upgrade_nodes is failed' will never meet the conditional if 'faled_when: false' is applied here because you've told ansible to never fail the task.

Either you need to you 'ignore_errors: true' here (which is not great), or you need to change the conditional in the task below to check for something like 'when: overcloud_upgrade_nodes.rc != 0'.

I'll just delete the second sentence.

There are a few more limitations:

- IPv6 (Tempest tests are skipped)
- mixed IPv4 and IPv6 members
- limited load balancing algorithm. Most commonly used ones are not implemented (e.g. round robin, least connection, etc)
- Octavia flavors

There are other things not supported like TLS-terminated HTTPS load balancers and session persistence but given those are L7 capabilities, the first point (L31) covers it.

Sorry, please ignore my previous reply. I had thought this API was doing something to GET the AZ of a particular instance.

As you noted on IRC, this API is just listing all available AZs, which are user-facing and makes sense to be available to everyone. And correct it should not be admin-only because non-admin users need to be able to see what AZs they can use when they make a instance create request.

ironic/drivers/modules/drac/raid.py.message:
I don't think these lines are needed.  There are 2 paths that we can take to get here:
1. RAID controller does not support JBOD mode.  In this case, no jobs will have been created yet, so there's no need to wait.
2. RAID controller does support JBOD mode.  In this case, we're being called from _check_node_raid_jobs() and the job that we would be waiting for has finished already.

Could you rename conversion_results to something like commit_results?  In all the other places, conversion_results is a dictionary that maps controller ids to results for that controller.  In this case, the return value is None, CLEANWAIT, or DEPLOYWAIT.
I think this block of code should be moved before to line 1078, before _change_physical_disk_mode is called to prevent a very unlikely race condition from occurring.

author.name: Julia Kreger
author.status: On the moon! With a jetpack!

ironic/drivers/modules/drac/raid.py.message: Hey Julia, this method is only called when the delete_configuration cleaning step is executing, and it is the last substep in the chain.  As a result, the default substep of "completed" is used, which indicates it's the last substep.

It was not needed here actually because it is a last operation(substep) as a part of the the cleaning(delete_configuration) step and so it will take by-default substep which is ``completed`` at line https://review.opendev.org/#/c/707169/3/ironic/drivers/modules/drac/raid.py@842 . It will resume the cleaning step and put the node to `cleaning` state from `clean wait`.

releasenotes/notes/upgraded-create-confi.message: It may be helpful to reword this because I think your wanting to express that the issue is that the task could proceed to the next step prematurely while already in cleaning.

Hey Rachit, how about something like this:

Fixes a bug in the ``idrac`` hardware type where when creating one or more virtual disks on a RAID controller that supports passthru mode (PERC H730P), the cleaning step would finish before the job to create the virtual disks actually completed.  This could result in the client attempting to perform another action against the iDRAC that creates a configuration job, and that action would fail since the job to create the virtual disk would still be executing.

Hey Rachit, how about something like this:

This patch fixes this issue by only allowing the cleaning step to finish after the job to create the virtual disk completes.

i looked more onto it and found downgrading zipp will not help as issue is due to mixing of old version of contextlib2 in queens and some pypi packages from source, i see two option to move forward:-
1)
   - name: install virtualenv in quickstart venv
     when: release in ['queens']
     pip:
       name: virtualenv
or 2)
   - name: Upgrade contextlib2 system
     become: true
     when: release in ['queens']
     pip:
       name: contextlib2>0.5.0,<0.6.0
       extra_args: '-U --force-reinstall'

I don't think we need to add a new goal and a new strategy.
the rollback actionplan should be a new actionplan belong to that audit. so I think that maybe we need to add a new audit api to create the rollback actionplan, such as shell cmd 'watcher audit revert audit_id'.
We can define a new function in class AuditEndpoint to process the rollback request. In this function, creating a solution from actionplans that have been executed, and then invoking planner.schedule to create the reverting actionplan.
And  the main function can be put in /watcher/decision_engine/audit

One continous audit may last a long time, and the CDM has changed dramatically. The rollback mechanism may not work well. 
I suggest to add rollback to actionplan, instead of audit. To make the rollback mechanism to work as far as possible,
only recent(for example, recent in one hour) actionplan is allowed to rollback.
If we bring the rollback mechanism, I think it's better to add 'revert' action to actionplan API.
For CONTINUOUS audit, maybe more than one actionplan had been triggered, when reverting, we need to revert all the changes,so we need the audit uuid to get all the actionplans.

Ok, thanks efried, the analysis is very clear, I understand, thank you, I will pay attention to this in subsequent reviews.

I like this way [1], use two "()", I think it's clear and easy to distinguish.

[1]https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/service.py#L343-L346

It’s tough to spot (which is why it wasn’t caught during review), but it’s the difference between

 msg = _(“...fmt...” % args)

and 

 msg = _(“...fmt...”) % args

In the first one, variable interpolation is done on the (untranslated) marker string. Since the translation logic matches the marker string complete with format codes (%(foo)s etc), the result is most likely that this wouldn’t be “found” in the catalog and therefore not translated. TL;DR: you would see this message in English instead of your chosen/configured language. 

The second example shows how it’s supposed to work: the translation function operates on the raw marker string, so you get a translated format string complete with codes. *Then* the args are substituted in.

> I like this way [1], use two "()", I think it's clear and easy to
 > distinguish.
 > 
 > [1]https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/service.py#L343-L346

In that one, I think they chose to use outer parentheses rather than putting the opening brace of the args dict on the same line (or using a backslash). I don't think it was for clarity.
yeah, to distinguish the translated string, formatting keywords have to be separated.

Side note: we’re not supposed to do this. Technically we’re supposed to maintain two different messages, one translated and one not, and use the former for the exception and the latter for logging. That would be a separate change though, and there are a million more casesthat could be fixed.
We don't translate logs anymore. This chunk is probably a holdover from when we did. So in this case you would see a translated log message in the middle of untranslated ones.
but every log supposed to be translated in translation right? I mean we do not need to keep English message along with same translated logs.

ah yeah, got your point now. +1.
I am sure most of the projects are not cleaned up for that.
How is the above change different from here?
yeah, issue is for localization string.

The way I'd lay down this logic is:

 3.1) IPA version is new enough? Reject.

Anyway, we need ensure it pass zuul test before merge.
why 4 threads? and 1 process I suppose it should be vice versa

It seems this boils down to mod_wsgi vs mod_uwsgi (at least in Apache2 terms)

For uwsgi, indeed one process + multiple threads may be preferable.

However for mod_wsgi, multiple threads won't work, and multiple processes + single thread in each must be used.

actually there are several reasons not to set it like this:
1. the defaults in nova chart for this are processes=4 threads=1 
2. placement-api does not support threads, so setting threads in wsgi settings can negatively affect performance
3. it is pretty hard to override this because I will need to override full config

I think you can override it according to your requirement.
By default, I think it is OK.  Any further comment? Thanks!
Zhipeng

I think you're misunderstanding how wsgi daemon process threads work. It's not about threads in the placement-api itself. It's about threads in the listener, each of which can handle (at any one time) a single placement-api request.

You're correct that placement does not use threads within itself. This is entirely by design. We want the web server and the operating system to manage concurrency and not have to worry about it within the Python code. This is okay and efficient because a single request to the placement service is an entirely linear process: get some data, process that data, get some more data, send that data. There is little opportunity for within request concurrency.

So what we want is opportunities for multiple requests to be handled, independently, which is the job of the web server and operating system.

In a container based environment I tend to keep number of processes low and raise threads. On bare metal or VM I would raise processes.

However, I completely agree with you that this should be far more configurable and some kind of templating would be good here.

Because in the end, every installation's requirements will be different and there is no good default.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
im not opposed to this although networking-ovs-dpdk is not intended to be the most optimal way of deploying ovs-dpdk

it shoudl use sane defaults and work in most cases including in a ci env or your local laptop for doing feature work on openstack to integrate ovs-dpdk.

so more docs are great, we can look at changing some defualt or adding some addtional options, but we should not try to tune it to use every last cycle to achive the best possible performance.

for example i have for a very long time intended to remvoe
'-O3 -march=native' form here

https://opendev.org/x/networking-ovs-dpdk/src/branch/master/devstack/libs/ovs-dpdk#L433

in favor of allowing you to specify them compile optimisation via EXTRA_CFLAGS or some other way.

i woudl still like to default to -O2 or -Os to have a sane default but -O3 actully hurts compile/ci job execution time and has also reduced performance in the past depending on the gcc/icc version. 

so i would prefer to move in teh direction of telling people how to optimise and provideing a way for them to do that with good default the hard coding things like -O3.

-march=native pretty much always improves performace at the cost of portablity but since we are not going to be redistributing the binaries built as part of stacking im more ok with that then -O3 as we have definitely hit compiler/dpdk  bugs with -O3 in the past.

We understand.. a bit of clear documentation about how to achieve a little bit better performance is definitely helpful so folks jaws don't drop when they test this and assume DPDK jsut isn't worth it. However, we still lack pointers to additional performance enhancements that could be done, any suggestions Sean?
And regarding -O3, we could also document that with a couple of words and use -O2/O as default.

Trying to strike the right balance between documentation and automation.

they are recommended for the vswitch. we generally recommend you use a seperate 2mb hugepage pool for the vms.
OK and what are the performance implications/bottlenecks in each of the cases?

yes this is the most secure option of the 3 main dirver availabel. vfio-pci, uio_pci_generic and igb_uio.
uio_pci_generic is the lost performace option of the 3 but allows you to avoid taining your kernel by loadign the bsd igb_uio dpdk kernel module if you dont have a iommu aviable to use vfio-pci. e.g. in a vm case if you dont want to taint your kernel you should use uio_pci_generic but on a physical host you should use vfio-pci in almost all cases bar uefi/firmware issues that prevent it form working.

Maybe we can add another sentence stating it's the recommended driver when running DPDK in a physical machine.

Sean do you have a good link where what you stated is already summarized?

that is only partly true.

the flavor must request memory_mb that is a multiple of the hugepage size and it must request hugepages using hw:mem_page_size=large|2MB|1GB

even though you use ovs-dpdk with vm that do not have hugepages we do not support that with openstack.

if you use the file backed memory feature it might tecnically work but if you do not use the file backed memory feature or hugepages for the vm on an ovs-dpdk host it will not have network connectivity.

this is not really a perfomance optimisation.
in fact i think setting the iommu=pt parmater actully reduces perfomance in some cases. this is really a requirement for using vfio-pci for the dpdk physical interface.

if you use igb_uio or uio_pci_generic this is not technically required.
This should go into the prerequisites section in a different patch.

again that isnt the recommenation we make.
the recomenation is to allocate 2 pools of hugepages and use 1G hugepages for ovs and 2mb hugepages for

Where is the recommendation?
Is that better for performance?

actully the default is still  igb_uio
https://opendev.org/x/networking-ovs-dpdk/src/branch/master/devstack/settings#L44

that was intentionally chosen so that we could run ovs-dpdk in vms for ci testing since uio_pci_geneirc was not bundeled on all kernels by default and has even less testing then igb_uio does.

so yes you should use vfio-pci when you can.
im not sure we should chagne the defautl to igb_uio although i have considerd doign that a few times so im not against it but this statement is incorrect.

the default driver for use in production with dpdk has been vfio-pci for years. no one has recommend using igb_uio in production since dpdk got full support for vfio-pci.

For backwards compatibility, please also add the old name.

kolla_toolbox_pip_virtualenv_packages|customizable("pip_virtualenv_packages")customizable("pip_packages")

Please also add a TODO comment to remove the old name in the next release.
The bug is about it exactly. Adding it back will not fix the issue.

This one is a wrong parameter for customizable filter, not export to user in template override, and also customisation for kolla_toolbox_pip_virtualenv_packages/kolla_toolbox_pip_packages never works from pike actually.

Users override kolla_toolbox_pip_virtualenv_packages with override/append/remove won't work and also make the following  kolla_toolbox_pip_packages cannot override also.

See https://github.com/openstack/kolla/blob/1e4cf4517165b4e6bca1a84e837dccbd10a33686/kolla/template/filters.py#L27-L35

I tested the following and it worked:

$ cat << EOF > to.j2
{% extends parent_template %}
{% set kolla_toolbox_pip_packages_append = ['foo'] %}
EOF

$ python tools/build.py --template-only kolla-toolbox --template-override to.j2

I know it doesn't follow the pattern, but if someone has worked around it we should try not to break them - especially on stable branches.

tripleo_ansible/roles/tripleo_ceph_run_a.message: hmm not sure if you can/should rework that with |product https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/user_guide/playbooks_loops.html#with-nested-with-cartesian to check all both of them in one task using a loop? i mean ceph_ansible_environment_variables and calling_ansible_environment_variables

I think I get the goal, but the log file name was hardcoded previously so if we don't need to deal with that in this change, I'd keep it for a follow up and remove the "complications" from this submission which ultimately looks good

We could just use the cluster name to build up the log file, like you do for the .sh scripts; more about that in another comment

I don't just want to get ANSIBLE_LOG_PATH. I need to know where it came from. So I specifically want to know if ANSIBLE_LOG_PATH is in ceph_ansible_environment_variables first since that's what's going to take precedence. Only if it's not there do I want to know if it is in calling_ansible_log_path.

I think if I combine the two into one loop, then I won't achieve my goal of knowing where it came from.

If it's in both ceph_ansible_environment_variables and calling_ansible_log_path, then I want to ensure I ignore the one in calling_ansible_environment_variables and only use the one in calling_ansible_log_path.

Why do I want to do this?

If someone overrides the log path for the config-download ansible run, then all ansible runs (including ceph-ansible) will log there. However, if they do that and also override the log path for the ceph-ansible run, then this method let's us obey their request; log all config-download ansible runs to one log but log the ceph-ansible runs to another log they specify.

As per our conversation on IRC I've left this as is. My reasoning is the following. If you didn't see it this way though or have more questions then just let me know.

- Because we're running multiple playbooks the logs could be confusing so we can include the logging in this change
- It's very useful to have line 112 tell the user where the log is
- It's already possible that the user will override the log path for the config-download and ceph-ansible log path so we need to find the log path anyway if we're going to log in a different location.
wouldn't this always be logging the script name? previous line was showing the actual playbook being started because the line was within a for loop

It's not clear in the log, without the above, which deployment the ceph-ansible run was for (1st internal, 2nd external, Nth external) so having that line in the log let's the user search for the context point.
I'd move external_ as part of the prefix

If a ceph-ansible shell script execution fails it does not run the next script. Instead it drops to the next task which extracts debug information from stdout and stderr and then the following task displays it. An example of how this looks (with ansible colors) is in the image below. In the example the internal ceph install works but the first external ceph fails.

https://www.dropbox.com/s/0j8xgf84t1ft2ep/multiceph_error_eg.png?dl=0

pkg/document/plugins/plugin_vars.go.message: Is this block needed -- doesn't the block below also handle the "in == varActualName" case?

yes but logic is different if value contains only variable (e.g "$(VAR)") we need to decide what to do: either treat variable value as string or as an object (map or array). 
If value is a string containing our variable (e.g. "some data $(VAR) more data") we just converting variable value to string and replace it with this string. Moreover it may turn out that value string contains more than one variable (e.g. "some data $(var1) data $(var2) more data")

pkg/document/plugins/testdata/varreferen.message: This map-looking format looks a little strange when I'm used to dealing with json path type path references.  However, it looks like this is the native format supported by Kustomize; is that correct?

this is one of the available formats in kustomize. it's needed when target key contain dot in its name. for example

kind: ConfigMap
data:
  key.with.dot: "some value"

so the only way to reference value in this case is "data[key.with.dot]"
